intent: Provide a structured ladder of authoritative cybersecurity sources (primary/secondary/tertiary) with access notes and when-to-use guidance.

definitions.primary: Normative or original sources: laws, regulations, official standards, official advisories, vendor security advisories, original research.
definitions.secondary: Interpretations and syntheses: security frameworks, guidance docs, textbooks, peer-reviewed reviews, professional handbooks.
definitions.tertiary: Convenience and orientation: encyclopedic summaries, checklists, blog explainers, high-level training resources.

primary.title: PIPEDA (Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act)
primary.whatItIs: Canada’s federal private-sector privacy law (baseline obligations around personal information).

primary.title: Privacy Act (Canada)
primary.whatItIs: Rules for how federal government institutions handle personal information.

primary.title: Criminal Code (Canada) — computer-related offences (selected provisions)
primary.whatItIs: Offences relevant to unauthorized access, mischief to data, fraud and related acts.

primary.title: Canadian Centre for Cyber Security (CCCS) advisories & guidance
primary.whatItIs: Threat alerts, mitigation guidance, baseline security guidance for organizations.

access.notes: Public advisories; operational details vary by doc.

primary.title: NIST SP 800-53 (Security and Privacy Controls)
primary.whatItIs: Comprehensive catalog of security/privacy controls; used as a control baseline and mapping target.

primary.title: NIST SP 800-61 (Computer Security Incident Handling Guide)
primary.whatItIs: Canonical incident response lifecycle and program guidance.

primary.title: NIST Cybersecurity Framework (CSF)
primary.whatItIs: Risk-based framework for organizing cybersecurity outcomes (Identify/Protect/Detect/Respond/Recover).

primary.title: ISO/IEC 27001 (ISMS requirements) & ISO/IEC 27002 (controls guidance)
primary.whatItIs: International standard for information security management systems and control guidance.

access.notes: Often paid; many libraries provide access to ISO standards portals.

primary.title: IETF RFCs (selected): TLS, HTTP, DNSSEC, OAuth/OIDC and related security RFCs
primary.whatItIs: Primary technical specifications for core internet security protocols.

primary.title: Vendor Security Advisories (Microsoft, Apple, Google, Cisco, OpenSSL, etc.)
primary.whatItIs: Official vulnerability disclosures, patch guidance, and mitigations.

access.notes: Always prefer original vendor/maintainer notice over reposts.

secondary.title: CIS Critical Security Controls (CIS Controls)
secondary.whatItIs: Prioritized set of security controls aimed at practical risk reduction.

access.notes: Many CIS resources are freely available; some are membership-gated.

secondary.title: OWASP Top 10 & OWASP Application Security Verification Standard (ASVS)
secondary.whatItIs: Widely used appsec risk list (Top 10) and verification standard (ASVS).

secondary.title: SANS reading room (whitepapers) & practitioner guidance
secondary.whatItIs: Practical syntheses; quality varies by paper but often useful for operations and training.

secondary.title: Security Engineering (Ross Anderson) — textbook
secondary.whatItIs: Foundational security engineering principles, threat models, and system design thinking.

access.notes: Common in libraries; some editions/chapters may be online.

secondary.title: Applied Cryptography (Bruce Schneier) / modern crypto references (varies)
secondary.whatItIs: Crypto concepts and patterns; use carefully for modern recommendations.

access.notes: Available in many libraries; pair with current standards (RFCs/NIST) for modern guidance.

tertiary.title: MITRE ATT&CK (tactics, techniques, procedures knowledge base)
tertiary.whatItIs: Curated catalogue of adversary behaviors used for detection engineering and threat modeling.

tertiary.title: MITRE CWE/CVE (weaknesses & vulnerabilities registries)
tertiary.whatItIs: Reference identifiers for software weaknesses and vulnerabilities.

tertiary.title: Wikipedia (orientation only)
tertiary.whatItIs: High-level summaries; useful for definitions but not authoritative for compliance or operations.

access.notes: Always verify with primary/secondary sources for anything operational or compliance-related.

tertiary.title: Vendor blogs & security researcher blogs (context, not authority)
tertiary.whatItIs: Fast-moving explanations and commentary; quality varies widely.

access.notes: Prefer original research writeups; confirm with advisories/standards.

retrievalDoctrine: Prefer primary sources for compliance, safety posture, and operational decisions.
Use secondary sources for structured program-building and best-practice synthesis.
Use tertiary sources for orientation only; never treat as decisive authority.
safetyGuards: If user requests offensive/illegal instructions, refuse and pivot to defensive guidance.
Avoid step-by-step exploit instructions; focus on detection, prevention, and recovery.
Minimize sensitive data handling; encourage privacy hygiene.
citationHinting: For legal/compliance claims: cite the specific statute/regulation/official guidance.
For incident-response process: cite NIST 800-61 or recognized national guidance.
For controls: cite NIST 800-53 / ISO 27001/27002 / CIS Controls as appropriate.
